Award.AwardTitle: Studies of the Early-1990s Climate Shift in the Pacific and Its Linkage to the Atlantic Multi-decadal Oscillation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in the climate of the Pacific Ocean and overlying atmosphere have worldwide consequences, and the causes and consequences of such changes are important topics in climate dynamics. One such change is the Pacific climate shift of the early 1990s, in which 1) the location of El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events shifted from the eastern equatorial Pacific to the central equatorial Pacific; 2) the year-to-year variability of the Northern Hemisphere monsoons decreased dramatically; 3) sea level in the western tropical Pacific began rising at a faster rate; and 4) the north equatorial current and countercurrent migrated southward. This project tests the hypothesis that the 1990s climate shift is related to an intensification of the subtropical Pacific high, a quasi-stationary region of high sea level pressure which extends past the dateline from the California coast and covers much of the subtropical North Pacific. When the subtropical Pacific high intensifies the surface winds circulating around it speed up, and the higher speed has the effect of strengthening the coupling of the ocean and atmosphere in the region. Work under this award examines the extent to which the intensification of ocean-atmosphere coupling can lead to the four climate shift impacts listed above. The project further tests the hypothesis that the intensification of the Pacific high occurred in response to the reversal of the Atlantic Multi-decadal Oscillation (AMO) which occurred at the same time. The AMO is a slowly varying mode of sea surface temperature (SST) variation in which the Atlantic north of the equator is either warmer or colder than average, with a transition from colder to warmer SSTs around 1990.

The research is conducted using a suite of simulations from a climate model configured in various ways to test the hypotheses. In one configuration SSTs are prescribed globally, with the AMO pattern imposed in the Atlantic so that the response of the Pacific high to the AMO can be assessed. Other configurations use a partially or fully interactive ocean model, allowing the changes in the Pacific high to affect SSTs and the subsurface ocean. These configurations allow the changes in ocean-atmosphere coupling and their hypothesized consequences to be examined.

Aside from its scientific interest, the 1990s Pacific climate shift has societal importance due to its worldwide impacts. The variability of monsoon systems is consequential for water resources, while the shift from eastern to central Pacific ENSO events has implications for the impacts of these events on the weather and climate of the US. In addition, the project provides support and training for a postdoctoral associate and two graduate students, thereby providing for the next generation of researchers in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Project Goals

There is substantial evidence that significant changes occurred in broad areas of the Pacific in the early 1990s. These changes in the ocean and atmosphere have likely altered the nature of ocean-atmosphere coupling and climate variability across the tropical and extratropical Pacific and require further understanding. This project hypothesized that there is an early 1990s climate shift in the Pacific and that this shift is caused by a phase change in the Atlantic Multi decadal Oscillation (AMO). The major goals of this project are (1) to further confirm the existence of the early 1990s climate shift with a focus on the Pacific sector, (2) to identify the physical mechanisms that enable the AMO to induce such a significant climate shift in the Pacific, and (3) to better understand the overall interactions between the Pacific and Atlantic. Research tasks have been successfully conducted to achieve all the project goals.

2. Outcomes confirming the existence of AMO-driven climate shifts in the Pacific sector during 1990s

Figure 1 summarizes the climate shifts that we identified and the associated climate phenomena.

Within the North Pacific, relationships between the Western Pacific Subtropical High and Northeastern Pacific Subtropical High changed from being out-of-phase before the early-1990s to in-phase afterward. Associated with the changed Pacific highs, surface wind stress patterns also changed and resulted in a rapid change in the North Pacific Ocean circulation around 1990s. The North Pacific subtropical gyre and the Kuroshio Current weakened rapidly during the late-1990s. We also discover an increasing influence of the AMO on the activities of Santa Ana wind events in recent decades.

Within the tropical Pacific, AMO-driven climate shifts are particularly clear in ENSO and monsoon properties and dynamics. We discover that ENSO's reoccurrence frequency, onset dynamics, and transition complexity all experienced a rapid shift in the early 1990s when the AMO switched from its negative to positive phase. El Nino (La Nina) events after the early 1990s tended to reoccur every other year giving rise to a strong biennial frequency of ENSO. The onset dynamics of ENSO shifted from being dominated by tropical Pacific couplings before 1990s to being dominated by subtropical Pacific couplings afterward. Associated with this change, the ways that the ENSO transitions from one event to another have also become more complex. After the AMO switched phase in the early-1990s, the western North Pacific monsoon has replaced the Indian monsoon to become one major monsoon center of the tropospheric biennial oscillation phenomenon.

Within the South Pacific, we discover that an early-1990s changes exist in the relationships between ENSO and the two leading modes of Southern Hemisphere atmospheric variability: the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) and the Pacific-South American (PSA) pattern. Through the ENSO connection, the PSA and SAM became more correlated after the early-1990s. The ENSO forcing also became more important to the Antarctic climate after early-1990s.

3. Outcomes in understanding the physical mechanisms enabling the AMO to induce climate shifts in the Pacific

In this project, we successfully (1) develop a wave source theory to explain how the phase change of the AMO in the early-1990s can induce climate shifts in the Pacific (Fig. 2), (2) identify a cause of model deficiencies in simulating this AMO impact on Pacific climate and develop a revised AMO index to alleviate the model deficiency, and (3) obtain a better understanding of the different origins of the 1990s and 1970s climate shifts in the Pacific sector. We show that the 1970s climate shift in the Pacific was originated within the Pacific Ocean, while the recent 1990s climate shift was linked to AMO-related trans-basin forcing.

4. Outcomes in understanding the overall inter-basin interactions between tropical and extratropical Pacific and Atlantic

A teleconnection method was developed to identify the hot spots of inter-basin interactions among the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans. The study identifies regions of strong inter-basin interactions that were not previously known, which include (1) the Indian Ocean has a strong interaction with the north Pacific where the Pacific warm blob events often occur and (2) the northwestern Pacific has strong interactions with the tropical and South Atlantic.

5. Broader impacts from the outcomes 

The understandings obtained from this project have broader impacts in that they add new insights on how the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans may affect each other to cause rapid climate shifts. The new understanding also has the potential to lead to improvements in decadal climate predictions. The understanding obtained can also help in developing new ways to interpret paleoclimate proxies of Earth's past climate. Finally, the project trained graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and undergraduate students in the rapidly growing Earth System Science Department at University of California, Irvine.
